Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Invariants of Decision Making

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Innovation in science, technology, economics, health, and other areas of human activity fundamentally hinges on discovering and leveraging invariances - those aspects of a system that remain stable across different contexts. In this research project, the PIs will identify the invariance properties reflected in individual decision making -- invariances across individuals, across choice contexts, and across choice tasks. Understanding of invariants of decision making behavior (and their boundaries) has broad implications in industry, national security, consumer financial decision making, health decision making and others, particularly in designing decision support systems, in understanding consumer behavior, and in enhancing citizen protection against financial and cyber-predators.

The project has three components: 1) to specify mathematically precise formulations of scientific questions about invariants of decision making, 2) to conduct laboratory studies of such invariants, 3) to develop advanced statistical and computational techniques for the analysis of the obtained data. The team will study a range of customized mathematical models that may open up new avenues to understanding invariance in decision making. Building on a long research tradition in multiple disciplines, the team will study in the laboratory how decision makers trade-off between rewards and risk, rewards and time delays, and examine the principles that guide decision making. The novelty of the research resides in its mathematical tools and in its focus on invariance: across individuals (individual differences), across choice contexts (different choice options), and across choice tasks (say, risky choice vs. inter-temporal choice). An additional novel emphasis of the project is to discover biological markers of invariants in decision making, examined with respect to MRI measures of neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, and brain function, and by investigating nutrient biomarkers of health and nutrition.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans make important decisions involving uncertainty, time, resources, and trade-offs throughout their lives.  These choices are not confined to a single domain.  The same individual will, over his or her lifetime, make small scale, medium impact, and life-altering financial decisions (e.g., how to save for retirement), health related decisions (e.g., choosing treatment options versus "watchful waiting"), and environmental decisions (e.g., whether to purchase carbon footprint reducing technologies). To model individual choice accurately, it is critical that we understand how structural aspects of the decision making process change or stay invariant across different domains and people.  As the figure illustrates, the project considered invariance of various mathematical features across choice sets (the options that are available to the decision maker), across tasks, across contexts, and across either individuals or populations, such as young versus elderly people. All of these types of decisions and all of these properties of the decision making process, when scaled to the level of the nation, have enormous economic, political, public health, and environmental impacts on society.  

 

The most important and powerful principle of scientific thinking is the concept of invariance. The greatest scientific milestones are insights into lawful relationships and the boundaries within which they hold. For example, physics, chemistry and astronomy have established amazingly powerful scientific insights through the discovery of invariances and through the systematic study of the conditions under which these invariances break down. Those insights have enabled, and continue to drive, engineering and technological innovation. This project provides leadership in pushing this scientific concept to the forefront in Decision, Risk and Management Sciences (DRMS) research. Some of the major new insights of this project provide new ways to model, evaluate, and understand the scope of scientific theories in decision making. A major goal is to let these discoveries about invariances and their boundary conditions drive innovation in DRMS applications and related applied disciplines. The team has developed software and a sequence of tutorials to facilitate the transfer of knowledge from a small number of research labs to a broad community in basic and applied research. The project already shows signs of impacting conceptual, theoretical, methodological and applied approaches in DRMS. The project has pursued four broad goals: 1) mathematically precise formulations of scientific questions about invariants of decision making, 2) empirical, experimental study of invariants of decision making in the laboratory, 3) advanced statistical and computational analysis of empirical data from human decision makers, and 4) efforts to render the approach broadly accessible to DRMS scholars, as well as to researchers in more applied disciplines. The team has published its findings in prestigious peer-reviewed scientific journals.

 

Quantitatively modeling invariants of choice behavior will better elucidate the cognitive processes underlying decisions.  Selecting among these processes, therefore, has critical implications for how people make such decisions.  Understanding invariants of choice can aid us in helping people make better decisions that achieve their long-term goals and improve well-being at the society level.
